title: Grilled Cheese at The Moxie
body:
Since we opened over a year and a half ago, one of the most frequent requests we've had is to add more "real food" to the Cinebar menu. If you were to come into The Moxie tonight, the only hunger-quenchers we have to offer are popcorn, candy, and our tasty baked goods from Tea Bar and Bites. While that selection is enough for most people, we still get requests for something a bit more substantial.

We've considered several options in the past: roasted nuts, hot dogs made from locally-grown beef, pizza, etc.. After considering the cost of equipment, and the space needed, we ended up nixing those ideas, but we recently starting consider something new... grilled cheese sandwiches.

What we're envisioning is having a choice of 3 or 4 different cheeses, a couple different types of bread, and maybe some special seasonings to really make the sandwiches POP in your mouth. We'd need to buy a professional panini grill, like the kind they use at Panera Bread, but that's really the only special equipment we'd need. And since cheese has a much longer shelf life than pizza or hot dogs, we won't have to be constantly throwing away uneaten food.

Now, this isn't something that's going to happen overnight, so don't expect to be able to order a delicious Moxie grilled cheese this weekend. We'll have to wait until we clear off our business credit card, which will probably be in the next month or two, before we can afford a high-quality panini grill, but after that... prepare to stuff yourself silly with the best grilled cheese sandwiches this side of the Mississippi!

AWESOME!

So what do you think? Would you partake of a tasty Moxie Grilled Cheese (MGC)?
author: Dan

comments.author: Master RJ
comments.body:
I'm for it.

By the way, Dan, are you afraid of losing business from the Dive-In Theatre that just opened? I'm just asking.

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Posted By: Master RJBy the way, Dan, are you afraid of losing business from the Dive-In Theatre that just opened?
Nope.

comments.author: moxie-lover89
comments.body:
grilled cheese sounds delighful. 
but i must know, where is this drive-in theater????

comments.author: dan
comments.body: It's the Dive-In Theatre, they're a new second-run theater downtown. You can check out their website here.

comments.author: tim
comments.body:
grilled cheese is brilliance. that and a beer. wow. 
how much would you consider charging for one of those there grilled guys?

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Posted By: timhow much would you consider charging for one of those there grilled guys?
I'm not sure yet. We'll have to wait and see how much the ingredients will cost us. I'd imagine somewhere around $3 or $4.

comments.author: HollywoodOz
comments.body:
I have two words for you - Craigs List.

Wait, is that one word or two?

There are tons of cafes and restaurants going out of business every day, and there's a lot of ex-restaurant equipment for sale on CL as a result. I nearly bought a big ass pizza oven for $1500 just last week. So close...

Seriously though, don't buy restaurant equipment new. It's shinier, but no better.

comments.author: HollywoodOz
comments.body: BTW, the Dive-In's testimonials page is a must-see.

comments.author: The Four Finger Soc Em
comments.body: I would buy a grilled cheese more often than not. My mouth is watering as we speak... well, until I used the phrase "my mouth is watering" just there, because that saying always turned me off. But I'm still ON for grilled cheese, oh baby!

comments.author: El Brian de Moore

i too would be all about this grilled cheese
especially the thought of exotic breads.. cheeses.. and seasonings....

and this dive in theater?  i somehow hadnt heard of it 
im sure ill check it out at some point.... but reading their website (which could use a better web designer.. err)
... i admit i am a bit apprehensive... ...im not much for people yelling and talking through a movie
maybe ill go see one that ive already watched many times over... to ensure that i dont get pissed off at people

comments.body:
grilled cheese...yumz...

And yeah - the whole talking during the movie thing at the Dive-in really turns me off to the whole idea. That and the fact that you have to watch it on an LCD unless you get the special projection screen seats. And their website....yeah.

I love the Moxie. :-)

comments.author: nate

Maybe it's runner up to the decision to marry each other, and then the decision to open the Moxie - maybe - but even that's only because those decisions were necessary prerequisites to making this grilled cheese sandwich thing happen. dear jesus.

comments.body:
My [enter religious diety here]!

That is the most [adjective] website I have ever seen.  It is worse than [competitor].com.  No one should ever put a website up for the public when it is still so [adjective].  Geesh, it is good to know [name and/or names] are making their site so personable.

[Name of poster]

comments.author: HonkeyHero
comments.body:
Yep... I'm all for a real tasty 'gourmet' grilled cheese... You guys and your market tapping extensions...

Just count on a lot more clean up...  (Melted cheese in the chairs!!!)

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Posted By: HonkeyHeroJust count on a lot more clean up... (Melted cheese in the chairs!!!)
That's another thing we considered, and one of the main reasons we decided not to do pizza. I don't know about you guys, but I've never made a mess with a grilled cheese sandwich. Plenty of crumbs, yes... but melted cheese? Do you open your sandwich and lick out the innards? Is that how they taught you to eat your sandwiches in Everton? Weird!

comments.author: nate
comments.body: Mmmm... lick innards.

comments.author: HonkeyHero
comments.body:
No, but I do remember a few instances in the old Everton Cafeteria where the Grill cheese was taken apart and the innards were used as glue to put under the seats or on a wall.  I know the Moxie would not allow these types of patrons anywhere near the theater.  I guess it would be kinda the same as letting people sit on couches in the Dive Theater and worrying about people peeing on the cushions of the couch to be funny.  Or not... I don't know... I'm from Dade County...

In other news... The federal reserve did not change interest rates... Fly Stocks fly

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Nicole is making me a grilled cheese sandwich right now. Here's the line-up:

Cinammon
Heavy wheat bread slice
4 apple slices
2 slices of mild cheddar
Heavy wheat bread slice
Cinammon

She's making herself an Italian grilled cheese, but I'm not sure what's on it.

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body: ill be right over!

comments.author: nate
comments.body:
Apple slices?!


The question/exclamation mark is not meant to indicate alarm/abhorrence, but rather some combination of surprise/intrigue/trepidation, probably in that order...

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body:
cheese and apples go very good together
though ive never had such a thing with bread in the mix... i cant imagine that it would be bad though
especially with cinnamin.... mmmm

comments.author: HonkeyHero
comments.body:
OK Dan, 

I guess I will be your Guinea Pig if you and Nicole would like to create several variations of the Grill Cheese, I will make a special trip to the Moxie tommorow and sample them for you.  You may observe my eating habits inside the theater as well, if you must.  I guess someone has to make the sacrifice in order to lead the Moxie to even more success...

Also you will have to figure out your profit margins on this endeavor, and make sure you don't cannibalize your profits! I.E. Popcorn is $2.50 but costs you .25c  Grill cheese cost $3.00 but costs $2.00 to make.  But I'm sure you are already considering this all, especially since you went to Billings and all...

comments.author: nate
comments.body: Employees first.

comments.author: dan
comments.body: The cinammon apple grilled cheese was delicious. The apples were warm on the outside, but still cold and crunchy in the center, and they complimented the cheddar cheese perfectly. I didn't use much cinammon, but I could taste it ever few bites.

comments.author: HonkeyHero
comments.body: Employees last, they would be biased!

comments.author: dan
comments.body:
Posted By: HonkeyHeroAlso you will have to figure out your profit margins on this endeavor, and make sure you don't cannibalize your profits! I.E. Popcorn is $2.50 but costs you .25c Grill cheese cost $3.00 but costs $2.00 to make. But I'm sure you are already considering this all, especially since you went to Billings and all...
That's sound advice, Honkey... as in, it sounds like something I already said. What can I expect though... you are from Everton.

comments.body:
You barely mentioned that...   If I was grading you would get half a point... ^..^  (which is still failing)  

I guess I need a new substitute since you are getting rid of my precious Ginger Ale...

comments.author: evilvet
comments.body:
Dan and Nicole:  How big of a Pannini maker do you need?  I think we may have a kitchen one lying around.  I know we have a classic american skillet (lightly used) that even has a grilled cheese setting we could lend you (Note:  The more times you get married, the more kitchen appliances you accumulate).

In the meantime, I have a great food holdover idea:  POP TARTS!  They are warm and addicting, incredibly nostalgic, and Dillon's carries every variety (generic and the real deal) ever conceived.  Heck, they could even be toasted by the customer according to their personal tastes.    DO NOT buy one of those You-Bake Waffle Irons for Moxie Waffle Lovers (Becca) they have at Comfort Inns.  They drive me nuts.

just give me the heads up and i will give you their cell digits. 

cool?

The filling is made from gelatin, which contain extract from animal bones.

comments.body: I looked it up - RJ is right, BUT I'm betting many vegetarians wouldn't care as much about gelatin, but I could be wrong. Vegans on the other hand...they definitely would.

comments.author: jhawk
HollywoodOz
comments.body:
Back when I was young enough to be proud of my stupidity, my buddies and I used to go to McDonalds a few times a week for eats. Our local McD's was located in what had previously been an old 40's ballroom, and then a roller disco, so it had these wicked high ceilings and all sorts of awesome art deco design that was half a century old... so of course we'd open our burgers and fling the pickle slices as high as we could to see if we could hit the roof.

After a few years of that, the black, blue and green pickles (they turn blue before they go black) numbered many dozens, and the manager of the place eventually cleaned it all up and, in doing so, painted over the art deco.

The moral of the story is 1) I'm a dick. 2) My buddies are dicks. 3) Careful what you put in those grilled cheese sandwiches, and that the individual bits won't stick to a screen when flung by bags o'douche.

Posted By: nicoleI'm a big fan of semi-soft cheeses. Not sure how those would taste in grilled cheese...plus it would be so fattening! But man, a brie grilled cheese? I've made baked brie before...
i just made a brie grilled cheese! well... broiled. on crispy french bread with maple syrup, walnuts, and a light dusting of chili powder. sooooooo goooooood.

comments.author: nate
comments.body:
Danicole:  Did you guys consider PB & J's?

Wait.  Who do I think I'm talking to?  Of course you considered it.  I guess I'm wondering why it was rejected.  Too blah and/or easily made at home to convince people to buy them?  I think you could sell them cheap... maybe $2, and that would be a good incentive, yes?  I'd buy the hell out of $2 PB & J's.  Don't kiss me after, though.

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body:
Posted By: nateI'm wondering why it was rejected.
do you want to scrub peanut butter and jelly off the seats, nate?

comments.author: nate
comments.body:
Is that worse than melted cheese?  There would be some smearage here and there, but no more than the cheese, I'd imagine.
And there would be no cheese-griller thing to clean every night either.

comments.author: nate
comments.body: Wait. Let me be clear, I'm not advocating PB&J's instead of grilled cheeses, but in addition to. I'm just saying, that if we're willing to clean a cheese-griller thingy every night, then should we rule out PB&J's because there will be a bit of jelly on the floor, and no cheese-griller thingy to clean? Just wonderin'.

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body: Ooh, good points. Yes, the cheese on the seats/floor will be a fun new addition to the Moxie. But I'm still excited for grilled cheese.

comments.author: dan
comments.body: I don't think the cheese will be a problem. Unlike jelly, cheese doesn't drip out of a properly grilled sandwich. It's also about appeal. I think grilled cheese would be more appealing to more people than PB&J.

comments.author: nate
comments.body: *sigh*

comments.author: The Four Finger Soc Em
comments.body: Plus, cheese isn't sticky.

comments.author: dan
comments.body: And futhermore, PB&J is pretty much just that... peanut butter & jelly, but imagine all the different varieties of grilled cheese we can make! With just TWO choices of bread, THREE choices of cheeses, and THREE choices of spice, you can make over 40 different kinds of grilled cheese sandwiches.

comments.author: tim
comments.body:
at the cafe in my alma mater, they had a huge basket in the fridge of giant PB & J's for 2 bucks a piece, i would have starved to death if it wasn't for those delicious nut buttered babies. cheap. filling. delicious. point is, no one can get sick of PB & J, they can be premade, and if served wrapped up in plastic, there would be no drippage, start at one end and and unwrap as you eat. perfect! 

do this too!!!! 

ORANGE SODA AND PB&J would be the bees knees.

comments.author: tim
comments.body:
Posted By: danAnd futhermore, PB&J is pretty much just that... peanut butter & jelly, but imagine all the different varieties of grilled cheese we can make! With just TWO choices of bread, THREE choices of cheeses, and THREE choices of spice, you can make over 40 different kinds of grilled cheese sandwiches.
nope! there are many types of nut butters, breads, and jelly, spices, and fruits. nutella and bananas! fluffernutters! almond butter with black berry jam! PB & Honey seriously, think of the combinations !!!!

comments.author: nate
comments.body:
I was thinking the pre-made route too, wrapped in plastic, though that limits tim's mega combination extravaganza that he also suggests.  Seems to me like you have to go one route or the other.
But whatever.  I'm just happy with the grilled cheese thing.  And the combinations!

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body: Heh heh. Tim is making some very good points...and it wouldn't require the purchase of a grill...

comments.author: EdMo
comments.body:
Feta is excellent grilled...maybe a Mediterranean grilled cheese?

Feta, olive tapenade (sp?), romaine lettuce?

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body:
now... ... before i say anything.. let me explain that i *LOVE*  PB & J
i have in stock a variety of different kinds of peanut butter and jelly at all times
... have you seen some of the new flavors they've of peanut butter come out with over the past few years?  its insane!!

but never the less... i really dont like the thought of pb&j being at the moxie
thats something ... anyone could make

but having special recipe... super fancical (not a word) grilled cheeses.... 
now that is just plain genius.. and cant be easily recreated
also ... (as dan stated and i already kinda thought) my brain cant imagine cheese 
dripping out of a grilled cheese sandwich very easily... but obviously jelly would be all over the place
unless you didnt put much on it... but i wouldnt want a PBJ with only a little *J* in the mix

comments.author: jhawk
comments.body: Messy? Unpossible...

comments.author: Ian
comments.body: Bring on the grilled cheese and put it in my mouth.

comments.body: you guys don't know what you're talking about. walnuts are obviously the best nut. And The Moxie is on Walnut! So how perfect would it be to sell "The Walnut Special" (or something cleverly named by Danicole instead of my cheesy attempt) and it would have WALNUTS ON IT!!!

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body:
the walnut *street* special

.... but either way cashews are the best nut... everyone knows that

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body: I love cashews, but I have a slight food allergy to them, and throw up when I eat them (unless if they're in something, like cashew chicken - then I'm usually fine).

comments.body:

yeah.

comments.author: The Four Finger Soc Em
comments.body: Man, I was so gross. I did eat ketchup sandwiches when I was kid. And nowadays on a good weekend.

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body:
Funny story. I loved ketchup as a kid. I ate it on everything. And I HATED mustard. With a passion. 

Now I LOVE mustard. And I still like ketchup but it's not what it used to be to my tastebuds.

comments.body: oooh....how about apple and cheese sandwiches!!

comments.author: The Four Finger Soc Em
comments.body:
If I could change one thing in this world... I would take all the mayonaise off the planet entirely and not allow it to ever be made again.

Yeah, THAT would be my one thing. For sure.

comments.author: EdMo
comments.body:
Awww....

I like Mayo.


::: Ed walks away, hanging head low::::

comments.author: ariananana
comments.body: Mayonaise is okay in like..egg salad.

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body:
Ok, I have been called "weird" many a time for liking this...but guess it's time I share:

I love mayo on my grilled cheese. I usually don't like mayo that much at all, but I LOVE it on grilled cheese. Try it sometime! 1 slice of bread (wheat!), 1 slice American cheese, mayo layer, 1 slice American cheese, 1 slice of bread (wheat!). I swear it's good.

comments.author: Becca
comments.body:
I read this (to myself and then out loud to Nathaniel) and then skipped the majority of the comments because I just wanted to say that Nathaniel's immediate reaction was hysterical laughter and a big "f- yeah."

I'm lactose intolerant myself, but I might be able to stomach a grilled cheese once in a while just 'cause it's such a great idea.

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body:
i think my reaction was very similar.. actually..  :-)

and ari... im pretty sure earlier in this thread... dan mentioned a apple and cheese grilled sandwich... with cinnamon even

comments.author: Seth
comments.body:
Grilled cheese would make me want to drop by the moxie, before I go to work, just for a grilled cheese.  

The Moxie and Merles Hotdogs should merge together...my friend suggested this possibility to me the other night and I can't quit thinking about how great chili cheese tots and a movie would be.

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body:
nooooooo

.... ian loves merle's 
i dont like it at all...
well i like their dessert treats
but ive noticed nothing at all special about their hotdogs... and they use regular.. cheap hot dog buns
and then it cost almost as much as hot dogs at a baseball game... or some such event
then ian would now say 'well i usually go on chili cheeto whatever day.. and its on special that day.. so its cheaper'  
eh... well .... i dont like chili cheeto whatever mixed together... it looks like a plate of puke
i like chili in a bowl with crackers and cheese... on a cold winter day
... not on a hot dog with cheetos on a hot summer day

did i get carried away there?  sorry im not in a great mood :-)

comments.author: ariananana
comments.body:
their hot dogs are ok, i admit to an indulgence in a chilli dog every once in a while. but GOOMZ that ooey gooey chocolate butter cake makes my heart sing.

What about casper's chili? i've allwaayyysss wanted to try it.

comments.author: nate
comments.body: Casper's chili = good.  But only every so often.

comments.author: El Brian de Moore
comments.body: ive never had the chili there either.. but they make damn good burgers

comments.author: jhawk
comments.body:
Posted By: El Brian de Mooreive never had the chili there either.. but they make damn good burgers
Cheeseburger with a side of chili from Caspers is a Medical Event waiting to happen, but it's SOOOOO good...

comments.author: ariananana
comments.body:
when do they open? 


and...i just ate THE grilled cheese that danicole has to have...

rye-pumpernickel swirl bread
provolone, sharp cheddar, pepperjack, gouda and allouette
and a little mustard for kicks!

comments.author: FaultyGoblin
comments.body:
A grilled cheese sandwich with Marmite on it is one of life's greatest joys.

Otherwise some provolone, peppered tomatoes, with prosciutto, on fresh bread toasted in olive oil = yum.
Every now and again some ragu sauce with Edam on top is excellent.
But kudos on the grilled idea, its real food that everyone likes, boo on the pb&j

comments.body: Prosciutto +eggplant+cream cheese+crusty french bread+BBQ sauce = The Steve

comments.author: Cosmik
comments.body: It would be cool if, during the 2008 Around the World festival (or Passport or whatever it was called since I can never get down to the Moxie for all those foreign films), you had a special Grilled Cheese sandwich for the country of each film's origin (during it's run, of course, not everything all summer.)  Like, a grilled gruyere and pear for France, grilled cheese, spam and egg for Britain, Grilled kaiser cheese with saurkraut on rye for Germany, that sort of thing.

comments.author: nicole
comments.body: We may team up this year and do food for each film, and give-aways from Pastiche (because they always have global items). I'm excited!

comments.body: oh my gosh, that sounds awesome.
